results.headline: Prison Comedy With a Shank, Not an Ax
results.summary_short: “Let’s Go to Prison” is a sly, very funny comedy that stays admirably deadpan every time you think it’s about to veer into gross-out territory.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Let's Go To Prison

results.headline: The Ties That Bind America’s Food Chain
results.summary_short: The film adaptation of Eric Schlosser’s best-selling book is far too rich and complicated to be understood as a simple, high-minded polemic.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fast Food Nation

results.headline: An Argentine Director’s Unsettling Oeuvre
results.summary_short: With the exacting ruthlessness of a novel by Georges Simenon, "The Aura" tells the story of an ordinary man caught up in a web of crime, accident and mistaken identity.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of El Aura

results.headline: A Love Triangle Caught Between Dreams and Reality
results.summary_short: Stephen and Timothy Quay merge live-action and animation to create a tragic fantasy about a beautiful opera singer, a lovesick piano tuner and the mad scientist with plans for both of them.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Piano Tuner Of Earthquakes

results.headline: In Ancient Japan, Lover Divided by a Tragic Twist of Fate
results.summary_short: Named for ninjas equipped with superhuman capabilities, Ten Shimoyama’s “Shinobi” is equal parts tragic love story and fantastical martial arts showcase.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Shinobi

results.headline: Renewing a License to Kill and a Huge Movie Franchise
results.summary_short: The latest James Bond vehicle finds the British spy leaner, meaner and a whole lot darker.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Casino Royale

results.headline: Bring in Da Hoofers on Ice
results.summary_short: Even in a story about singing-and-dancing fat and feather, the director George Miller can’t help but go dark and deep.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Happy Feet

results.headline: On Opposite Sides, United by Grief
results.summary_short: It isn’t often that you see a film about Israelis and Palestinians that can be called hopeful, but Ronit Avni’s assured, thoughtful and clear-eyed documentary certainly qualifies.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Encounter Point

results.headline: The Cast of a Film Catches a Bad Case of the Oscars
results.summary_short: “For Your Consideration” is by far the broadest comedy Christoper Guest and company have made. Despite its merriment, it is also the flimsiest.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of For Your Consideration

results.headline: Flying Up, Up and Away, Then Down, Down, Down
results.summary_short: This Australian film doesn’t add anything substantively new to the story of heroin addiction, though it does feature striking performances from Heath Ledger and Geoffrey Rush.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Candy

results.headline: The Way We Were, Way Back in June of ’68
results.summary_short: With “Bobby,” Emilio Estevez tries to link the intimate stories of nearly two dozen characters to a large and consequential public event — the assassination of Robert F. Kennedy.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bobby

results.headline: One Feisty Woman Takes On the Art World
results.summary_short: Harry Moses’s entertaining documentary portrays the debate between connoisseurship and science as a culture war.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Who the #$&% is Jackson Pollock?

results.headline: If You Listen, You’ll Hear Adulthood Approaching
results.summary_short: A pair of disaffected 17-year-olds are nudged toward adulthood in a movie that favors natural drift over artificial drama.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dance Party, USA

results.headline: A Marriage Fumbles. Let’s Go to the Video.
results.summary_short: The twin specters of Ingmar Bergman and Woody Allen hover over this talky history of a relationship between two New Yorkers.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Flannel Pajamas

results.headline: A Young Woman Sickened by a Triple Shot of Stalkers
results.summary_short: The horror movie workhorse Sarah Michelle Gellar is back to chill us with “The Return,” a rote thriller with an intriguingly frenetic shooting style.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Return

results.headline: Stopping to Smell the Vintner’s Bouquet
results.summary_short: "A Good Year," an innocuous, feel-good movie that reunites Russell Crowe with the director Ridley Scott, is a three-P movie: pleasant, pretty and predictable. One might add piddling.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Good Year

results.headline: Beware of a Prince Who Serves You Frog
results.summary_short: In “Come Early Morning,” Ashley Judd delivers her most natural screen performance since “Ruby in Paradise,” the film that pushed her toward stardom in 1993.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Come Early Morning

results.headline: When Buddy (Psychotic) Meets Buddy (Weakling)
results.summary_short: In “Harsh Times,” Christian Bale gives a spectacular technical performance as an unhinged war veteran running amok in South Central Los Angeles.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Harsh Times

results.headline: A Visual Chronicler of Humanity's Underbelly, Draped in a Pelt of Perversity
results.summary_short: “Fur” is a folly, though not a dishonorable one.
results.display_title: Fur: An Imaginary Portrait of Diane Arbus

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fur: An Imaginary Portrait of Diane Arbus

results.headline: Hearing Voices? It's Just Somebody’s Imagination
results.summary_short: While "Stranger Than Fiction" traffics in a bit of darkly funny existential anxiety, it also finds room for romantic fantasy and sentimental uplift.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Stranger Than Fiction
